content.title: Foreword
content.description:
This Technical Specification has been produced by the 3rd Generation Partnership Project (3GPP).
The contents of the present document are subject to continuing work within the TSG and may change following formal TSG approval. Should the TSG modify the contents of the present document, it will be re-released by the TSG with an identifying change of release date and an increase in version number as follows:
Version x.y.z
where:
x	the first digit:
1	presented to TSG for information;
2	presented to TSG for approval;
3	or greater indicates TSG approved document under change control.
y	the second digit is incremented for all changes of substance, i.e. technical enhancements, corrections, updates, etc.
z	the third digit is incremented when editorial only changes have been incorporated in the document.

content.title: Introduction
content.description:
The present document is part of a TS-family covering the 3rd Generation Partnership Project; Technical Specification Group Services and System Aspects; Telecommunication management; as identified below:
TS 28.657		Evolved Universal Terrestrial Radio Access Network (E-UTRAN) Network Resource Model (NRM) Integration Reference Point (IRP); Requirements
TS 28.658		Evolved Universal Terrestrial Radio Access Network (E-UTRAN) Network Resource Model (NRM) Integration Reference Point (IRP); Information Service (IS)
TS 28.659		Evolved Universal Terrestrial Radio Access Network (E-UTRAN) Network Resource Model (NRM) Integration Reference Point (IRP); Solution Set (SS) definitions

content.title: 1	Scope
content.description:
The present document specifies the E-UTRAN network resource information that can be communicated between an IRPAgent and an IRPManager for telecommunication network management purposes, including management of converged networks.
This document specifies the semantics and behaviour of information object class attributes and relations visible across the reference point in a protocol and technology neutral way. It does not define their syntax and encoding.
The E-UTRAN NRM IRP comprises a set of specifications defining Requirements, a protocol neutral Information Service and one or more Solution Set(s).
The present document specifies the protocol neutral E-UTRAN NRM IRP: Information Service (IS). It reuses relevant parts of the Generic NRM IRP: IS in 3GPP TS 28.622 [6], either by direct reuse or sub-classing, and in addition to that defines E-UTRAN specific Information Object Classes.
In order to access the information defined by this NRM, an Interface IRP such as the "Basic CM IRP" is needed (3GPP TS 32.602 [7]). However, which Interface IRP is applicable is outside the scope of the present document.
The present document also specifies the ng-eNB network resource information that can be communicated among NG-RAN management system, including management of MR-DC operations which ng-eNB is involved in.

content.title: 2	References
content.description:
The following documents contain provisions which, through reference in this text, constitute provisions of the present document.
-	References are either specific (identified by date of publication, edition number, version number, etc.) or non-specific.
-	For a specific reference, subsequent revisions do not apply.
-	For a non-specific reference, the latest version applies. In the case of a reference to a 3GPP document (including a GSM document), a non-specific reference implicitly refers to the latest version of that document in the same Release as the present document.
[1]	3GPP TS 32.101: "Telecommunication management; Principles and high level requirements".
[2]	3GPP TS 32.102: "Telecommunication management; Architecture".

subsections.title: 3.1	Definitions
subsections.text_content:
For the purposes of the present document, the terms and definitions given in TS 32.150 [16], TS 32.101 [1], TS 32.102 [2] and TS 21.905 [17] and the following apply.
Association: See definition in TS 28.622 [6].
Network Resource Model (NRM): See definition in TS 28.622 [6].
eNodeB: A logical node responsible for radio transmission/reception in one or more cells to/from the User Equipment. 
It terminates the S1 interface towards the EPC.

subsections.title: 3.2	Abbreviations
subsections.text_content:
For the purposes of the present document, the abbreviations given in TS 32.150 [16], TS 32.101 [1], TS 32.102 [2] and TS 21.905 [17] and the following apply. An abbreviation defined in the present document takes precedence over the definition of the same abbreviation, if any, in TS 28.657 [39], TS 32.150 [16], TS 32.101 [1], TS 32.102 [2] and TS 21.905 [17], in that order.
DeNB	Donor eNodeB
DN	Distinguished Name (see 3GPP TS 32.300 [4])
E-UTRA	Evolved Universal Terrestrial Radio Access
E-UTRAN	Evolved Universal Terrestrial Radio Access Network
MBSFN	Multimedia Broadcast multicast service Single Frequency Network
NCR	Neighbour Cell Relation
PM	Performance Management
RDN	Relative Distinguished Name (see 3GPP TS 32.300 [4])
RN	Relay Node

subsubsections.title: 4.1.1	Imported information entities and local labels
4.1.2	Associated information entities and local labels
4.2.1	Relationships
subsubsections.text_content:
This clause depicts the set of classes (e.g. IOCs) that encapsulates the information relevant for this IRP. This clause provides the overview of the relationships of relevant classes in UML. Subsequent clauses provide more detailed specification of various aspects of these classes.

Figure 4.2.1 - 1 presents a cell relation view, illustrating the interconnection of various cells within a cellular network. The figure showcases the hierarchical structure of the network, with macro cells, picocells, and femtocells positioned to optimize coverage and capacity. The figure also highlights the role of base stations (BSs) and their coordination with mobile stations (MSs) to ensure seamless communication. The visual representation emphasizes the importance of efficient resource allocation and handover management in maintaining high-quality service across the network.Figure 4.2.1-1 provides a detailed view of the interconnection of different cells within a cellular network, illustrating the hierarchical structure of the network. The figure showcases the positioning of macro cells, picocells, and femtocells to optimize coverage and capacity. It also highlights the role of base stations (BSs) and their coordination with mobile stations (MSs) to ensure seamless communication. The visual representation emphasizes the importance of efficient resource allocation and handover management in maintaining high-quality service across the network.
Figure 4.2.1-1: Cell relation view
Figure 4.2.1.1-1a presents a detailed view of the relationship between cells and frequencies in a telecommunication network. The figure illustrates how different frequency bands are allocated to various cells, with each cell represented by a distinct shape. The horizontal axis represents the frequency range, while the vertical axis denotes the number of cells. The overlapping cells indicate that multiple frequency bands are shared among them. This visual representation helps in understanding the efficient utilization of spectrum resources and the potential interference between adjacent cells. The figure emphasizes the importance of proper frequency planning and coordination in modern cellular networks.
Figure 4.2.1.1-1a: Cell and frequency relation view
NOTE A:	The above NRM fragment uses SubNetwork to hold both NR and LTE external entities and frequencies.
Figure 4.2.1.1-1b presents a detailed view of the relationship between cells and frequencies in a telecommunication network. The figure illustrates how different frequency bands are allocated to various cells, with each cell represented by a distinct shape. The horizontal axis represents the frequency range, while the vertical axis denotes the number of cells. The overlapping cells indicate that multiple frequency bands are shared among them. This visual representation helps in understanding the efficient utilization of spectrum resources and the potential interference between adjacent cells. The figure emphasizes the importance of proper frequency planning and coordination in modern cellular networks.
Figure 4.2.1.1-1b: Cell and frequency relation view
NOTE B:	The above NRM fragment uses NRNetwork to hold NR external entities and frequency and using EUtraNetwork to hold LTE external entities and frequency. The NRNetwork and EUtraNetwork are subclasses of SubNetwork (defined in TS 28.622[6]) with no additional attributes. The reason using NRNetwork and EUtraNetwork is for a clean separation of NR external entities and frequency and LTE external entities and frequency.

The given telecommunication figure illustrates the relationship between different entities within a network, specifically focusing on the association between ENBFunctions and RNFunctions, as well as the management of these functions by IRPAgent instances. The figure emphasizes the presence of two types of associations: ServesRN and ServesExtRN, which dictate whether the ENBFunction and RNFunction instances are managed by the same or different IRPAgents. This diagram is crucial for understanding the network's organization and the roles of various components in managing and coordinating network functions.
NOTE 1:	If an instance of the ServesRN association is present, then a corresponding instance of ServedByEGC must be present. In this case, the ENBFunction and RNFunction instances are under the management scope of the same IRPAgent. 
If an instance of the ServesExtRN association is present, then a corresponding instance of ServedByExtEGC must be present. In this case, the ENBFunction and RNFunction instances are under the management scope of two different IRPAgents.
NOTE 2:	The modelling of the DeNB capability as a separate IOC or as attributes of ENBFunction is FFS
Figure 4.2.1-2: E-UTRAN relaying view of E-UTRAN and ng-eNB NRM


Figure 4.2.1-3 provides a detailed transport view of E-UTRAN and ng-eNB NRM, illustrating the various components involved in the communication process. The figure showcases the physical and logical layers, including the eNB, gNB, and the transport network. It also highlights the role of the RRC protocol stack, PDCP, and the MAC layer in facilitating efficient data transmission. The figure emphasizes the importance of synchronization and timing in maintaining the integrity of the communication system. Overall, this diagram offers a comprehensive overview of the transport view of E-UTRAN and ng-eNB NRM, emphasizing the complexity and precision required in modern telecommunications networks.
Figure 4.2.1-3: Transport view of E-UTRAN and ng-eNB NRM

Figure 4.2.1 -4: MBMS view of E-UTRAN NRM 1

This telecommunication figure illustrates the Multimedia Broadcast Multicast Service (MBMS) view of Evolved Universal Terrestrial Radio Access Network (E-UTRAN) Network Resource Management (NRM) 1. The figure provides a detailed overview of the MBMS system in the context of E-UTRAN NRM 1, showcasing the various components and their interactions.

The figure is divided into two main sections: the MBMS system and the E-UTRAN NRM 1. The MBMS system is depicted on the left side of the figure, while the E-UTRAN NRM 1 is shown on the right side. The MBMS system includes the MBMS network, the MBMS network elements, and the MBMS network interfaces. The E-UTRAN NRM 1 includes the E-UTRAN NRM 1 system, the E-UTRAN NRM 1 network elements, and the E-UTRAN NRM 1 network interfaces.

The figure also includes a legend that explains the symbols used in the figure, such as the MBMS network
Figure 4.2.1-4: MBMS view of E-UTRAN NRM 1
NOTE 1: This is E-UTRAN NRM containment/relationship Figure form view of MBMS when MCE and ENB belong to one Network Element.
Figure 4.2.1 -5: MBMS view of E-UTRAN NRM 2

This telecommunication figure illustrates the Multimedia Broadcast Multicast Service (MBMS) view of Evolved Universal Terrestrial Radio Access Network (E-UTRAN) Network Resource Management (NRM) 2. The figure provides a detailed overview of the MBMS signaling process within the E-UTRAN network, showcasing the various stages and interactions between different network entities.

The figure is divided into multiple sections, each representing a different aspect of the MBMS signaling process. The top section shows the MBMS signaling flow, which includes the MBMS signaling from the eNB (evolved Node B) to the Serving Gateway (SGW) and the Home Location Register (HLR). The middle section illustrates the MBMS signaling from the SGW to the Gateway G (GWG) and the Serving Gateway (GWG). The bottom section depicts the MBMS signaling from the GWG to the Home Location Register (HLR) and the Serving Gateway (SGW).

The figure also includes various network entities such as the eNB, SGW, GWG, and HLR, which are essential for the proper functioning of the
Figure 4.2.1-5: MBMS view of E-UTRAN NRM 2
NOTE 2: This is E-UTRAN NRM containment/relationship Figure form view of MBMS when MCE and ENB belong to different Network Elements.
Figure 4.2.1-6: SON related Attributes NRM IOCs (Containment Relationship)

Figure 4.2.1-8 illustrates the WLAN Mobility Set NRM for LWA and LWIP, showcasing the dynamic movement of wireless devices within a Local Area Network (LAN) and how these movements are managed to ensure seamless connectivity. The figure highlights the role of the Mobility Management Entity (MME) and the Serving Gateway (SGW) in controlling the handover process, which is crucial for maintaining stable connections during device movement. The figure also emphasizes the importance of Quality of Service (QoS) management and the use of Licensed Assisted Access (LWA) and Licensed-Wired Interoperability Protocol (LWIP) for efficient resource allocation and optimal performance.Figure 4.2.1-7: Non-collocated LWA NRM
Figure 4.2.1-8: WLAN Mobility Set NRM for LWA and LWIP
Figure 4.2.1-9 presents an IoT-related attribute NRM IOCs, illustrating the network's infrastructure and communication protocols. The figure showcases the interconnection of various network elements, including gateways, routers, and access points, which facilitate seamless data transmission and communication between IoT devices and the network. The figure emphasizes the importance of security measures, such as firewalls and intrusion detection systems, in protecting the network from potential threats. Additionally, the figure highlights the role of Quality of Service (QoS) in ensuring that critical IoT applications receive the necessary resources for optimal performance. Overall, the figure provides a comprehensive overview of the network's architecture and its key components, emphasizing the need for robust security and efficient resource allocation to support the growing number of IoT devices.
Figure 4.2.1-9: IoT-NTN related Attributes NRM IOCs

subsubsections.title: 4.2.2	Inheritance
subsubsections.text_content:
Figure 4.2.2-1: E-UTRAN NRM Inheritance Hierarchy illustrates the hierarchical structure of E-UTRAN Network Reliability Management (NRM) in a telecommunications system. The figure shows the various levels of NRM, from the network level down to the UE level, highlighting the interdependencies and responsibilities of each entity in ensuring network reliability. The figure emphasizes the importance of coordination and communication among network elements to maintain seamless service delivery and user experience.
Figure 4.2.2-1: E-UTRAN NRM Inheritance Hierarchy

subsubsections.title: 4.3.1	ENBFunction
subsubsections.text_content:
This IOC represents eNB functionality defined in TS 36.300 [11] or ng-eNB defined in TS 38.300 [41]. For more information about the eNB, see 3GPP TS 23.002 [19]. For more information about the ng-eNB, see 3GPP TS 38.300 [41].




NOTE 1:	The above mentioned SON or MDT related conditions do not apply to ng-eNB.

The common notifications defined in subclause 4.5 are valid for this IOC, without exceptions or additions.

subsubsections.title: 4.3.2	ExternalENBFunction
subsubsections.text_content:
This IOC represents an external eNB functionality. For more information about the eNB, see 3GPP TS 23.002 [19].
None.
The common notifications defined in subclause 4.5 are valid for this IOC, without exceptions or additions.

subsubsections.title: 4.3.3	EUtranGenericCell
subsubsections.text_content:
This abstract IOC represents the common properties of an E-UTRAN generic cell provided by eNB function or an NG-RAN generic cell provided by ng-eNB function. For more information about E-UTRAN cells, see 3GPP TS 23.401 [9]. For more information about NG-RAN cells, see 3GPP TS 38.300 [41].
Note 1:	No state propagation is implied.
Note 2: 	The attribute value change is conveyed by the notifyStateChange notification.
Note 3:	For NB-IoT, as indicated in the relevant subclauses in TS 36.300 [12], a number of E-UTRA protocol functions supported by all UEs are not used for NB-IoT and need not be supported by eNBs and UEs only using NB-IoT. The attributes cellLocalId, tac, pci, maximumTransmissionPower are Mandatory for NB-IoT cell, Whether other attributes are needed for NB-IoT cell are out of scope of this document.
Note 4:	The attribute PCI is writable when the NM-Centralized PCI assignment (see TS 32.500 [15] clause 6.1.6) is supported.
Note 5:	The attribute maximumTransmissionPower is writable when IOC SectorEquipmentFunction is not used.

The common notifications defined in subclause 4.5 are valid for this IOC. In addition, the following set of notification, defined in 3GPP TS 32.662 [32], is also valid.
.

tables.description: The common notifications defined in subclause 4.5 are valid for this IOC. In addition, the following set of notification, defined in 3GPP TS 32.662 [32], is also valid.

subsubsections.title: 4.3.4	ExternalEUtranGenericCell
subsubsections.text_content:
This abstract IOC represents the properties of an E-UTRAN generic cell controlled by another IRPAgent. This IOC contains necessary attributes for inter-system and intra-system handover. It also contains a subset of the attributes of related IOCs controlled by another IRPAgent. The way to maintain consistency between the attribute values of these IOCs is outside the scope of the present document.


The common notifications defined in subclause 4.5 are valid for this IOC, without exceptions or additions.

subsubsections.title: 4.3.5	EUtranCellFDD
subsubsections.text_content:
This IOC represents the properties of E-UTRAN FDD cell provided by eNB or NG-RAN FDD cell provided by ng-eNB..

None.
The common notifications defined in subclause 4.5 are valid for this IOC, without exceptions or additions.

subsubsections.title: 4.3.6	ExternalEUtranCellFDD
subsubsections.text_content:
This IOC represents the common properties of external E-UTRAN FDD cell provided by eNB or NG-RAN FDD cell provided by ng-eNB.
None.
The common notifications defined in subclause 4.5 are valid for this IOC, without exceptions or additions.

subsubsections.title: 4.3.7	EUtranCellTDD
subsubsections.text_content:
This IOC represents the properties of E-UTRAN cell TDD provided by eNB or NG-RAN TDD cell provided by ng-eNB.
None.
The common notifications defined in subclause 4.5 are valid for this IOC, without exceptions or additions.

subsubsections.title: 4.3.8	ExternalEUtranCellTDD
subsubsections.text_content:
This IOC represents the common properties of external E-UTRAN cell TDD provided by eNB or NG-RAN TDD cell provided by ng-eNB.
None.
The common notifications defined in subclause 4.5 are valid for this IOC, without exceptions or additions.

tables.description: This IOC represents the common properties of external E-UTRAN cell TDD provided by eNB or NG-RAN TDD cell provided by ng-eNB.

subsubsections.title: 4.3.9	EUtranRelation
subsubsections.text_content:
This IOC represents a NCR from a source cell to a target cell, where the target cell is a EUtranGenericCell or ExternalEUtranGenericCell instance.
The source cell can be an EUtranGenericCell instance. This is the case for an Intra-E-UTRAN NCR.
The source cell can be a UtranGenericCell instance. This is the case for Inter-RAT NCR from UTRAN to E-UTRAN. See 3GPP TS 28.652 [21].
The source cell can be a GsmCell instance. This is the case for Inter-RAT NCR from GERAN to E-UTRAN. See 3GPP TS 32.652 [20].
NCRs are unidirectional.

The common notifications defined in subclause 4.5 are valid for this IOC, without exceptions or additions.

subsubsections.title: 4.3.10	Link_ENB_ENB
subsubsections.text_content:
This IOC represents the link between two ENBFunction.
None.
None.
The common notifications defined in subclause 4.5 are valid for this IOC, without exceptions or additions.

subsubsections.title: 4.3.11	Cdma2000Relation
subsubsections.text_content:
This IOC represents a NCR from one EUtranGenericCell to a CDMA2000 sector. NCRs are directional.
See 3GPP2 TS S.S0028 [22]


None.
The common notifications defined in subclause 4.5 are valid for this IOC, without exceptions or additions.

subsubsections.title: 4.3.12	 MCEFunction
subsubsections.text_content:
This IOC represents MCE functionality. For more information about the MCE, see 3GPP TS 36.300 [11].
None.
None.
The common notifications defined in subclause 4.5 are valid for this IOC, without exceptions or additions.

subsubsections.title: 4.3.13	 MBSFNArea
subsubsections.text_content:
This IOC represents MBSFN Area. For more information about MBSFN Area, see 3GPP TS 36.300 [11].
None.

subsubsections.text_content:
This IOC models the M2 reference point as defined in TS 36.300 [11].
None.
None.
The common notifications defined in subclause 4.5 are valid for this IOC, without exceptions or additions.

subsubsections.text_content:
This IOC models the M3 reference point as defined in TS 36.300 [11].
None.
None.
The common notifications defined in subclause 4.5 are valid for this IOC, without exceptions or additions.

subsubsections.title: 4.3.16 	RNFunction
subsubsections.text_content:
This IOC represents Relay Node (RN) functionality. For more information about RN, see 3GPP TS 36.300 [11].
None.
The common notifications defined in subclause 4.5 are valid for this IOC, without exceptions or additions.

subsubsections.title: 4.3.17	 ExternalRNFunction
subsubsections.text_content:
This IOC represents the properties of a Relay Node (RN) controlled by another IRPAgent. For more information about RN, see 3GPP TS 36.300 [11].
None.
None.

subsubsections.title: 4.3.18	DeNBCapability
subsubsections.text_content:
This IOC represents the capability for an eNodeB to act as a Donor eNodeB (DeNB) functionality. For more information about the DeNB, see 3GPP TS 36.300 [11].
None.
The common notifications defined in subclause 4.5 are valid for this IOC, without exceptions or additions.

subsubsections.title: 4.3.19	CellOutageCompensationInformation
subsubsections.text_content:
This IOC represents information relevant in case of a Cell Outage Compensation taking place.
None.
The common notifications defined in subclause 4.5 are valid for this IOC, with the addition that notifyAttributeValueChange shall be supported (Support Qualifier M).

subsubsections.title: 4.3.20	 QciDscpMapping
subsubsections.text_content:
This IOC represents a set of mapping between QCI and DSCP.
N one.

subsubsections.title: 4.3.21 	EUtranCellNMCentralizedSON
subsubsections.text_content:
This abstract IOC represents the properties of an E-UTRAN generic cell which relate to SON functions. Its purpose is to enable configuration and tuning of the cell behaviour by the operator for SON functions which are not (yet) implemented in the eNodeB. NMS level SON should consider when configuring and tuning the cell the correlation of different attributes to optimise the eNodeB and network performance. For more information about cells, see 3GPP TS 23.401 [9].

The common notifications defined in subclause 4.5 are valid for this IOC, without exceptions or additions.

subsubsections.title: 4.3.22	WTFunction
subsubsections.text_content:
This IOC represents WT functionality defined in TS 36.300 [11].

None.
The common notifications defined in subclause 4.5 are valid for this IOC, without exceptions or additions.

subsubsections.title: 4.3.23	EP_Xw
subsubsections.text_content:
This IOC represents the end point of Xw reference point defined in TS 36.300 [11].
No additional attributes to the ones inherited from the IOC EP_RP defined in TS 28.622 [6].
None.
The common notifications defined in subclause 4.5 are valid for this IOC, without exceptions or additions.

subsubsections.title: 4.3.24	WLANMobilitySet
subsubsections.text_content:
This IOC represents the managed WLAN mobility set for LWA and LWIP. For more information about the WLAN mobility set, see 3GPP TS 36.300 [11].

None.
The common notifications defined in subclause 4.5 are valid for this IOC, without exceptions or additions.

subsubsections.title: 4.3.25	MemberWLAN <<datatype>>
subsubsections.text_content:
This <<datatype>> represents the information about a member WLAN of a WLAN mobility set.

None.
The subclause 4.5 of the <<IOC>> using this <<dataType>> as one of its attributes, shall be applicable.

subsubsections.title: 4.3.26	PLMNId <<dataType>>
subsubsections.text_content:
This <<dataType>> represents the information of a PLMN identification.

None.
The subclause 4.5 of the <<IOC>> using this <<dataType>> as one of its attributes, shall be applicable.

subsubsections.title: 4.3.27	EUtranFreqRelation
subsubsections.text_content:
This IOC, together with the target EUtranFrequency, represents the frequency properties applicable to the referencing cell relation.


The common notifications defined in subclause 4.5 are valid for this IOC, without exceptions or additions.

subsubsections.title: 4.3.28	EUtranFrequency
subsubsections.text_content:
This IOC represents certain E-UTRAN frequency properties.

None.
The common notifications defined in subclause 4.5 are valid for this IOC, without exceptions or additions.

subsubsections.title: 4.4.1	Attribute properties
4.4.2	Constraints
subsubsections.text_content: None.

subsubsections.title: 4.5.1	Alarm notifications
subsubsections.text_content: This subclause presents a list of notifications, defined in [18], that IRPManager can receive. The notification header attribute objectClass/objectInstance, defined in [37], would capture the DN of an instance of an IOC defined in this IRP specification.

subsubsections.title: 4.5.2	Configuration notifications
subsubsections.text_content:
This subclause presents a list of notifications, defined in [32], that IRPManager can receive. The notification header attribute objectClass/objectInstance, defined in [37], would capture the DN of an instance of an IOC defined in this IRP specification.

The following sequence diagrams and table show an example how notifications of IOC CellOutageCompensationInformation and other notifications are used to inform an IRPManager about the COC activities.
The sequence diagrams show the basic event flow, the table gives more details on selected, most relevant, content of the notifications.

Figure A-1: Sequence diagram of COC, part 1


Figure A-2: Sequence diagram of COC, part 2
Legend for the table: 
Notifications in italic font are not directly triggered by COC activities, but help to give a full picture.:
Notification content in bold font indicates a changed attribute value.
*) Remarks:
There may be some content of the correlatedNotifications and/or additionalInformation field, which is not related to COC. This additional content is not shown for better readability and must be kept unchanged by COC.
NotificationId’s are only examples.

Notification content in bold font indicates a changed attribute value.
